case_metadata.title: Case 10111: An American automobile mechanic of thirty-seven

medical_history.past_medical_conditions: Pleurisy (7 years ago), frequent 'colds', physiological glycosuria (1.5 years ago), stiffness of the neck and pain in the back of head (1.5 years ago), dry hacking cough (6 months ago), muscle pains in legs and back (1 week ago), slight chills (1 week ago), frontal headache (6 weeks ago), weight loss.
medical_history.medications: Diet for glycosuria (1.5 years ago), Collar (for neck stiffness)

turn_1.speaker: Caregiver
turn_1.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Upon Arrival
turn_1.message: He hasn't been himself for a few days. He's been so drowsy, and today he just became irrational. He's forgetting words and using the wrong ones. I think his speech is slurred.
turn_1.intention: Providing chief complaint and recent symptom onset
turn_1.context: Patient's wife describing the patient's condition upon arrival at the hospital.
turn_1.source_reference: # Case 10111, Paragraph 2: 'For the past three days he had grown increasingly drowsy. The day of admission he became irrational. He seemed to forget words and to use incorrect words. His wife thought his speech was thick and his articulation poor.'

turn_2.speaker: Nurse A
turn_2.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Initial Assessment
turn_2.message: Okay, I understand. We'll get him checked in right away. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on?
turn_2.intention: Acknowledging caregiver's concern and initiating history taking
turn_2.context: Nurse beginning the admission process and gathering initial information.
turn_2.source_reference: Implied from clinical setting - admission and initial patient assessment.

turn_3.speaker: Caregiver
turn_3.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Providing History
turn_3.message: Well, for about a year and a half, he's had a stiff neck and head pain. It got so bad he couldn't turn his head and had to change jobs. Sometimes he'd be bedridden because of it. And for the past week, he's had a bad headache, muscle pains, chills… like the flu.  He's been coughing too, but not much coming up.
turn_3.intention: Describing the patient's history of present illness
turn_3.context: Patient's wife elaborating on the patient's symptoms and timeline.
turn_3.source_reference: # Case 10111, Paragraph 2: 'For the past year and a half he had had stiffness of the neck and pain in the back of his head... Six weeks before admission he began to have severe frontal headache, worse toward evening. A week ago he began to have severe muscle pains in the legs and back... He also had slight chills... During the week he had had unproductive cough.'

turn_4.speaker: Nurse A
turn_4.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Gathering Past Medical History
turn_4.message: Has he had any other health problems in the past?
turn_4.source_reference: Implied from clinical setting - standard medical history questions.

turn_5.speaker: Caregiver
turn_5.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Providing Past Medical History
turn_5.message: He broke his leg as a kid, and about seven years ago he had pleurisy. He gets colds often. Oh, and about a year and a half ago, they found sugar in his urine. He was on a diet and lost weight, but then it went away. He's gained some weight back since then, but he's still not his normal weight.
turn_5.context: Patient's wife providing details about past medical conditions and weight changes.
turn_5.source_reference: # Case 10111, Paragraph 1: 'He broke his leg when a boy. Seven years ago he had pleurisy. Since that time he had been subject to frequent "colds." A year and a half ago sugar was found in his urine and he was placed on a diet upon which he had lost weight... On returning to ordinary diet he gained ten pounds, but never regained his normal weight. His best weight, eight years ago, was 200 pounds; his present weight 162.'

turn_6.speaker: Doctor E
turn_6.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Physical Examination
turn_6.message: Hello, I'm Dr. Lord.  Can you tell me what's been bothering you?
turn_6.intention: Introducing himself and initiating patient interaction for physical examination
turn_6.context: Dr. Lord starting the physical exam.
turn_6.source_reference: # Case 10111, Last Paragraph Before Discussion: 'The day of admission Dr. Lord found...'

turn_7.speaker: Patient
turn_7.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Physical Examination - Patient Response (Confused)
turn_7.message: (Confused and drowsy) My… eyes… headache… hurts…
turn_7.intention: Expressing chief complaint but with confusion
turn_7.context: Patient's drowsy and confused state during physical examination.
turn_7.source_reference: # Case 10111, P.E. Paragraph: 'A stalwart man, drowsy and mentally clouded, confusing his mouth with his eyes, and confused when asked to move his extremities. He complained of headache...'

turn_8.speaker: Doctor E
turn_8.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Physical Examination - Findings
turn_8.message: Okay, I see.  Nurse, his neck is very stiff and painful. He's also having trouble following commands.  I hear some dullness and râles in his left lung apex when I listen to his chest.
turn_8.context: Dr. Lord noting key findings during the physical exam.
turn_8.source_reference: # Case 10111, P.E. Paragraph: 'Neck stiff and painful on motion... Lungs. Dullness, bronchial breathing and coarse râles at the left apex in front... The day of admission Dr. Lord found dullness and medium consonating and sonorous râles at the left apex.'

turn_9.speaker: Doctor A
turn_9.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Reviewing Initial Findings
turn_9.message: So, thirty-seven-year-old mechanic, admitted today with drowsiness, confusion, stiff neck, and lung findings. History of neck stiffness for a while, recent headache, muscle pains, and cough.  Lumbar puncture was done, fluid is clear with high cell count, mostly lymphocytes.  Wassermann negative. We also have the old orthopedic records mentioning a possible tuberculous abscess in the neck and spinal tuberculosis.
turn_9.intention: Summarizing patient's presentation and initial findings
turn_9.context: Dr. Cabot reviewing the case details.
turn_9.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Notes on the History and P.E., Lumbar puncture results paragraph: 'An American automobile mechanic of thirty-seven entered December 9 for study... For the past year and a half he had had stiffness of the neck... Lumbar punctures. December 9. 10 c.c. clear colorless fluid... 280 cells, 3% polynuelears, 77% lymphocytes, 20% mononuclears. Wassermann and gold solution negative.'

turn_10.speaker: Doctor A
turn_10.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Differential Diagnosis Discussion
turn_10.message: Pulmonary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis seem like the most likely possibilities given the lung findings, spinal fluid, and history of possible neck tuberculosis. What do you think about the spine involvement?
turn_10.intention: Proposing a differential diagnosis and questioning spine involvement
turn_10.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Differential Diagnosis Paragraph: 'This reads like a perfectly straight ease of pulmonary tuberculosis with tuberculous meningitis. Whether there is anything in the spine or not I do not feel clear.'

turn_11.speaker: Doctor C
turn_11.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Questioning Meningitis Timeline
turn_11.message: Doctor, do you think the meningitis started when the neck stiffness began, or is it more recent?
turn_11.intention: Questioning the onset of meningitis in relation to neck stiffness
turn_11.context: Physician seeking clarification on the timeline of meningitis.
turn_11.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Physician's question: 'A Physician : Do you believe he had meningitis all the time he had stiff neck?'

turn_12.speaker: Doctor A
turn_12.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Responding to Meningitis Timeline Question
turn_12.message: No, I don't think so. The neck stiffness could be from that abscess they found in his neck earlier.
turn_12.intention: Differentiating cause of neck stiffness from meningitis onset
turn_12.context: Dr. Cabot explaining the likely cause of neck stiffness.
turn_12.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Dr. Cabot's response: 'Dr. Cabot : No. I think that was due to his abscess.'

turn_13.speaker: Doctor C
turn_13.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Questioning Abscess Tuberculosis
turn_13.message: But they didn't find tuberculosis in that neck abscess, did they?
turn_13.intention: Questioning the tuberculous nature of the abscess based on negative findings
turn_13.context: Physician questioning the diagnosis of tuberculous abscess.
turn_13.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Physician's question: 'A Physician : And in that abscess no tuberculosis was found?'

turn_14.speaker: Doctor A
turn_14.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Responding about Abscess Tuberculosis
turn_14.message: We wouldn't necessarily expect to find it in pus drained from an abscess like that. Especially if it was opened in the Out-Patient Department.
turn_14.intention: Explaining why tuberculosis might not have been found in the abscess
turn_14.context: Dr. Cabot explaining the difficulty of finding TB in drained pus.
turn_14.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Dr. Cabot's response: 'Dr. Cabot : We should expect that... It was opened in the Out-Patient Department, and I never knew them to find tuberculosis in the pus so obtained.'

turn_15.speaker: Doctor D
turn_15.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Sterile Abscess Suggestion
turn_15.message: A sterile abscess often points towards tuberculosis, doesn't it?
turn_15.intention: Suggesting sterile abscess as indicative of tuberculosis
turn_15.context: Dr. Young suggesting the nature of sterile abscess.
turn_15.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Dr. Young's comment: 'Dr. Young: It was a sterile abscess, which usually means tuberculosis.'

turn_16.speaker: Nurse A
turn_16.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, After Lumbar Puncture
turn_16.message: How are you feeling now after the lumbar puncture? Is your headache any better?
turn_16.intention: Assessing patient comfort and pain level after procedure
turn_16.context: Nurse checking on the patient post lumbar puncture.
turn_16.source_reference: # Case 10111, Last Paragraph Before Discussion: 'The patient was much more comfortable after the first lumbar puncture.'

turn_17.speaker: Patient
turn_17.timestamp: December 9th, Day of Admission, Patient's Response after Lumbar Puncture
turn_17.message: Yes, actually, the headache is a bit better right now.
turn_17.intention: Reporting improvement in headache after lumbar puncture
turn_17.source_reference: # Case 10111, Last Paragraph Before Discussion: 'The patient was much more comfortable after the first lumbar puncture.'

turn_18.speaker: Nurse A
turn_18.message: Doctor's orders are for Morphine 1/6 grain subcutaneously twice each night as needed for pain.
turn_18.intention: Administering medication as per doctor's order
turn_18.source_reference: # Case 10111, Orders - December 12: 'December 12. Morphia gr. 1/6 s.c. twice each night p.r.n.'

turn_19.speaker: Nurse A
turn_19.message: Doctor also ordered Pyramidon 5 grains today.
turn_19.intention: Administering medication as per doctor's order
turn_19.source_reference: # Case 10111, Orders - December 13: 'December 13. Pyramidon gr. v.'

turn_20.speaker: Nurse A
turn_20.timestamp: December 14th, Hospital Day 5, Medication Order Change
turn_20.message: Doctor has changed the morphine order. Now it's 1/6 to 1/4 grain every two hours as needed.
turn_20.intention: Administering medication as per updated doctor's order
turn_20.source_reference: # Case 10111, Orders - December 14: 'December 14, 15 and 16. Morphia gr. 1/6 to 1/4 once to every two hours p.r.n.'

turn_21.speaker: Nurse A
turn_21.timestamp: December 16th, Hospital Day 7, Medication Order Change for Delirium
turn_21.message: For tonight, the doctor has ordered Chloral hydrate and sodium bromide by rectum at 3 AM and 9 PM for his delirium.
turn_21.intention: Administering medication for delirium as per doctor's order
turn_21.context: Nursing staff implementing treatment plan for nighttime delirium.
turn_21.source_reference: # Case 10111, Orders - December 16: 'December 16. Chloral hydrate gr. xxx with sodium bromide gr. 50 by rectum at 3 a.m. and 9 p.m.'

turn_22.speaker: Nurse A
turn_22.message: Doctor Cabot, the patient had a very restless night despite the medications. His delirium is worsening, and his headache is much worse again. He passed away this morning.
turn_22.intention: Reporting patient's condition deterioration and death
turn_22.context: Nurse reporting patient's condition and outcome to Dr. Cabot.
turn_22.source_reference: # Case 10111, Last Paragraph Before Discussion: 'He had marked delirium at night, somewhat controlled by morphia, but gradually increasing after the second lumbar puncture. The headache grew rapidly worse. December 17 he died.'

turn_23.speaker: Doctor A
turn_23.timestamp: December 17th, Day of Death, Post-mortem Diagnosis Consideration
turn_23.message: So, he died. Clinically, it strongly pointed to tuberculous meningitis and pulmonary tuberculosis. Let's see what the post-mortem examination reveals.
turn_23.intention: Reflecting on clinical diagnosis and anticipating post-mortem findings
turn_23.context: Dr. Cabot considering the case after patient's death.
turn_23.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion - Differential Diagnosis and Clinical Diagnosis: 'I think he died of phthisis with tuberculosis of the meninges... CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS (FROM HOSPITAL RECORD) Tuberculous meningitis. Chief cause of death, disseminated tuberculosis (spine and lungs).'

turn_24.speaker: Doctor B
turn_24.message: Dr. Cabot, in the post-mortem, the meninges showed a slight granular exudate, suggestive of tuberculosis but not very pronounced macroscopically. However, microscopically, it is indeed tuberculous meningitis.
turn_24.intention: Reporting post-mortem findings confirming tuberculous meningitis
turn_24.context: Dr. Richardson reporting pathological findings from post-mortem examination.
turn_24.source_reference: # Case 10111, Anatomical Diagnosis - Dr. Richardson's Report: 'Dr. Richardson : The pia showed a thin slightly granular exúdate along the upper part of the medulla and extending up along the pons... Macroscopically it was suggestive of tuberculosis of the meninges, but not very well marked. Microscopical examination showed that it was tuberculous meningitis.'

turn_25.speaker: Doctor B
turn_25.message: The left lung has a large cavity in the apex with purulent material and tubercle bacilli.  There's also evidence of older tuberculosis in the bronchial glands and right lung apex.
turn_25.intention: Reporting post-mortem findings confirming pulmonary tuberculosis
turn_25.context: Dr. Richardson continuing to report pathological findings.
turn_25.source_reference: # Case 10111, Anatomical Diagnosis - Dr. Richardson's Report: 'In the apex of the right lung was a small fibrocaseous pigmented mass... In the apical region there was a cavity 5y2 by 4 cm. containing much purulent material. The cover glass from this material showed innumerable typical tubercle bacilli. Some of the bronchial glands showed obsolete tuberculosis.'

turn_26.speaker: Doctor A
turn_26.timestamp: Post-mortem Examination, Confirming Absence of Spinal Tuberculosis
turn_26.message: And what about the spine, any evidence of tuberculosis in the axis or cervical vertebrae?
turn_26.intention: Questioning about spinal tuberculosis based on earlier suspicions
turn_26.context: Dr. Cabot inquiring about spinal involvement.
turn_26.source_reference: # Case 10111, Discussion after Anatomical Diagnosis - Dr. Cabot's question: 'Dr. Cabot : You have no evidence on the question whether he may have had tuberculosis of the axis or any of the upper cervical vertebrae?'

turn_27.speaker: Doctor B
turn_27.message: No, Dr. Cabot, we couldn't find any evidence of tuberculosis in the vertebrae.
turn_27.intention: Reporting negative findings for spinal tuberculosis
turn_27.context: Dr. Richardson responding to Dr. Cabot's question.
turn_27.source_reference: # Case 10111, Anatomical Diagnosis - Dr. Richardson's Report: 'Dr. Richardson : There was nothing that we could make out.'

presentation.chief_complaint: Drowsiness, irrationality, headache, stiff neck, cough, muscle pains.
presentation.history_of_present_illness: 1.5 years of neck stiffness and head pain, 6 months of dry hacking cough, 6 weeks of frontal headache, 1 week of muscle pains, chills, unproductive cough, 3 days of increasing drowsiness, 1 day of irrationality, speech difficulties.
presentation.physical_exam: Drowsy, mentally clouded, confused, stiff and painful neck, dullness and bronchial breathing in left lung apex with râles, Kernig sign present, blurred fundi, temperature 101°-104.1°F, pulse 65-132 bpm, respiration 20-33/min.

laboratory_data.value: 30-40 leucocytes per high power field, Sp. gr. 1.018
Clear colorless fluid, 280 cells (77% lymphocytes, 20% mononuclears, 3% polynuelears), Albumin +++, Globulin ++, Sugar 0.031, Total protein 200, Wassermann and gold solution negative
laboratory_data.reference_range: Clear colorless fluid, Normal cell count, Albumin/Globulin/Sugar/Protein normal ranges

laboratory_data.value: Very slightly turbid fluid, 255 cells (90% lymphocytes, 9% polynuelears, 1 large mononuclear), No tb bacilli found, Numerous paired cocci (contamination?)
laboratory_data.reference_range: Clear colorless fluid, Normal cell count, No tb bacilli, No contamination

imaging.description: Lower cervical and upper dorsal spine normal. Appearance of first cervical vertebra abnormal, perhaps due to position. Two later plates gave no additional information.
imaging.findings: Lower cervical and upper dorsal spine normal, C1 abnormal appearance (positional)

imaging.description: Upper dorsal and lower cervical spine showed no positive evidence of disease in the vertebrae. Slight abnormality in relation of sixth and seventh dorsal.
imaging.findings: No vertebral disease, slight D6-D7 abnormality

imaging.description: Left lung field less radiant than right. Dullness at apex with obliteration of lung markings. Heart and mediastinal contents displaced to left. Diaphragm high on left, limited respiratory movements.
imaging.findings: Left lung opacity, apical dullness, mediastinal shift left, high left diaphragm

procedures.description: Diagnostic lumbar puncture on December 9th and December 14th
Tapping of neck abscess at Tuberculosis Clinic
Morphine, Pyramidon, Chloral hydrate, Sodium bromide

timeline_events.event: Sugar found in urine, diet started, weight loss, diagnosed with physiological glycosuria
Onset of neck stiffness and head pain
Severe muscle pains, chills, possible fever, unproductive cough
Irrationality, speech difficulties, admission to hospital, lumbar puncture
Second lumbar puncture, X-rays of spine and chest

final_diagnoses: Chronic tuberculosis of bronchial glands and apices of lungs
Tuberculosis of lungs with cavity formation
Slight hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart
